Award.AwardTitle: Evolution of the multivariate phenotype: phylogenetic tests of rates of size and shape evolution in salamanders
Award.AbstractNarration:
Biologists have long sought to understand how fast animals evolve in nature, and why organisms show such amazing morphological diversity. This project will study the pace of morphological change in two groups of salamanders that differ in how they interact with their environments. New methods will be developed for measuring rates of phenotypic evolution across the tree of life, and for comparing rates among groups of organisms. These methods will allow scientists to test potential explanations for why some groups evolve more rapidly than others.

This project contributes to our understanding of how fast evolution occurs, and how organisms in distinct environments respond to those conditions. Work on the project will give us a better understanding of how life changes over time, which is of great interest to biologists and scientists in other fields. Through this project, several educational outreach activities will also be conducted, including: a research-in-education exchange that includes students from a small college and students attending a large research university, and teaching workshops in quantitative methods to train the next generation of graduate students and scientists from around the world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Rationale: — Biologists have long sought to understand how fast animals evolve in nature, and why organisms show such amazing morphological diversity. However, we currently lack a robust set of statistical tools that allow biologists to study trait changes across the tree of life, and enable the analysis of morphological changes while accounting for the relatedness among taxa as described by their phylogeny.  This project fills that intellectual gap, with the development of analytical tools to describe how traits change over time, and by examining empirical systems comparing the pace of morphological change in two groups of salamanders that differ in how they interact with their environments. The newly developed methods will allow other scientists to test potential explanations for why some groups evolve more rapidly than others. 


Results: — Research on this project resulted in the production of 17 peer-reviewed publications (both empirical and theoretical), 7 software programs, 11 conference presentations, and 8 invited talks. Additionally, 3 undergraduate students, 1 graduate student, and one postdoctoral researcher were trained on the project, and the PI taught 8 international workshops which trained 116 scientists from around the world.

 

Through this project a series of statistical tools were developed that allow researchers to study the tempo and mode of evolutionary changes in morphological traits. Methods were developed to compare rates of evolution among traits, and rates of evolution across different groups of organisms. Additionally, phylogenetic comparative methods were developed for examining evolutionary patterns in multivariate datasets; a type of data of major concern to biologists but for which methods were previously lacking (multivariate phylogenetic signal, multivariate phylogenetic regression and multivariate phylogenetic correlation among others).

 

Additionally, work on cave-dwelling salamanders revealed that traits related to the biomechanics of climbing (foot shape) are under strong stabilizing selection, and that the invasion of novel habitats results in drastic shifts in foot morphology. Additionally, when viewed across the phylogeny foot morphology evolves more slowly in cave-dwelling species than traits not related to climbing, and when compared to non-climbing groups of salamanders. This demonstrates that current ecological selection pressures can exert strong macroevolutionary shifts in the pace of evolutionary change at broad phylogenetic timescales.

 

 

Broader Significance and Scientific Importance: — This project provides key evidence of how ecological selection at contemporary timescales can alter the tempo and mode of trait change at broad evolutionary levels. Thus the empirical work on the project serves as a template for how studies of the pace of evolutionary change may be conducted in other organisms. The project also provided new analytical methods that open the door to new avenues of investigation, and allow other researchers to examine such patterns in a phylogenetic context. Importantly, the project provided software for the implementation of these approaches. Educational Activities: The project has trained three undergraduates, one graduate student, and one postdoctoral researcher directly. Additionally, 116 scholars were trained through eight morphometric workshops taught by the PI. Societal impact: Results have implications for the conservation of turtles in the face of environmental change.
